Name: Ultimate Werewolf: Classic Movie Monsters
Description:
Ultimate Werewolf: Classic Movie Monsters is an expansion that includes six all-new roles, including The Blob, Frankenstein's Monster, Teenage Werewolf and more. For instance, The Blob slowly oozes across the village, one player at a time; if everyone in the village is part of The Blob, that player wins! Frankenstein's Monster gets special powers from other players as they die, becoming a great asset to the village as the game progresses. Teenage Werewolf is so excited to be a werewolf that each day he must say "Werewolf!"

This expansion is fully compatible with Ultimate Werewolf: Ultimate Edition, Ultimate Werewolf: Compact Edition,Ultimate Werewolf, and Ultimate Werewolf: Deluxe Edition.

Name: Doodle Pix
Description:
From manufacturer's website:

THE CLASSIC GAME OF PICS & SKETCHES

In this doodling game, players put their drawing skills to the test in a race against the clock. Players take turns drawing everything from athletic events to zoo animals. It’s a great game for parties and family get-togethers. Great content, great pricing, and eye-catching packaging!

Contents
-Doodle Pix Cards
-Game Board
-Game Pawns
-Drawing Pads
-Pencils
-Sand timer

Name: Who, What & Where
Description:
From the publisher:

THE CLASSIC GAME OF PEOPLE, THINGS & PLACES

This name-dropping party game challenges players to describe for their teammates a host of people, places and things it could be anything from Aladdin, Acupuncture, or Abbey Road to Zebras, Zurich, or even Zappa! Great fun for two teams and packed with content, this party in a box will get everyone guessing and laughing out loud.

Contents
-Who Cards, What Cards, Where Cards
-Game board
-Game pawns
-Sand timer

Name: Planeten Spiel
Description:
The gameboard is divided in seven fields, from the top to the bottom: 3, 1 & 3. At the top one can see the planets: Saturn, Jupiter and Mars. In the middle: the Sun. At the bottom: Venus, the moon of the Earth and Mercury.

Published in Augsburg, Germany.

Name: Der Siebener
Description: A gameboard with eleven panels, five to the left and right and one in the middle. Each panel has a joker and a number. The drinking joker in the middle is number 7. To the left one can see the numbers 2-6 and to the right 8-12.

Name: Team Talk
Description:
6 players: The players are divided into two teams, where one player is assigned to guess. The two other players in the same team now takes turn adding one word to a sentence about the word that has to be guessed.

4 players: The players are divided into two teams, one player from each team is assigne to guess. The other players now takes turn adding one word to a sentence about the word that has to be guessed.

Name: Flag Grid
Description:
Flag Grid is a two player game played on a 9x9 square board.
On each turn,a player must move one of his stones.
A stone moves(orthogonally or Diagonally)a number of cells equals to the number of stones in its row or column.
Wins the player that takes the flag into one of his own bases.

Name: Diamonds & Pivots
Description:
Diamonds & Pivots is a 2 player game played on an 5x5 hexagonal board.
Each player passes or drops a friendly stone over an empty cell.
If any diamond patterns with four friendly stones are made,the player must choose one,choose a stone from it(the pivot),and place its other three stones in a line starting from the pivot.
After two passes,wins the player with more stones.

Name: Sunshine
Description:
It is a very simple and delightful game for children age 4-7 years.
For 2 or 4 children.
All compete in removing the clouds from their section of the board and let the sunshine in.
The first player to do this is the winner.

Name: Apple Picking
Description:
All players pick apples from the trees, hoping to be the one who picks most.
Taking the top basket card from the pack a player picks as many apples as the cards says and places them in whichever basket it says.

Name: Zhēng Shàngyóu
Description:
This is a climbing game with many variations and therefore known by many names (Struggling Upstream, Pits, San Jia Xi, Huojian, Kuoppa). It's related to other climbing games like Dai Hin Min, Tien Len, Big Two and President.

The game is played with a 54-card pack including two jokers. Each player starts with a hand of cards and the object is to be the first to get rid of all your cards by playing combinations.

The game consists of playing combinations of cards: single cards, sets, single sequences and multiple sequences. When a player plays a combination, only a combination of the same type, length and higher rank can beat it - to beat a single sequence you must play a single sequence of the same length with higher ranking cards. Jokers are wild cards and can be used in any combinations. The Twos play a special role in this game and can be seen as semi-wild cards.

The player who gets rid of his cards first gets two points, the second player gets one point. You also get an extra advantage when finishing first or second, because the last and second to last player will have to give their best card away to them in the next hand.

Zheng Shangyou has a sizable luck element and the winner of a round has an advantage in the next round, but there is room for skillful play as the players learn how to best manage the cards they are dealt. The game plays best with five or six, but can be played by four or more. With 4 or 6 players, the game is usually played with two teams facing off against each other in partnerships.

Name: Das Spiel der Liebenden und Verliebten
Description: The gameboard is divided in 20 squares with depictions of 19 men, and one woman, in love. Some of the squares have depictions of dice.

Name: San Francisco 49ers Trivia Game
Description:
This sports trivia game features a plastic game board that uses a cribbage-style scoring system. Players move up and down the field as they answer questions about this NFL franchise.

Players can adjust the length of a game by changing the number of cards required to complete a "quarter" of play on the gridiron. There are two methods of play with the fast play mechanic allowing a player to keep moving the ball unitl he or she misses a question. The other meachanic has the players alternating play throughout the game.

Optional rules include Goal Line Stands, Interceptions, and Overtime. There are special cardboard dividers placed inside the question card deck to remind the players when halftime and other important points in the game will occur.

Includes the plastic stadium board, score markers, 2400 trivia questions on 400 cards, the time keeping dividers, a storage insert, a die, and rules.  
 Published in 1996 by Sports Games

Name: Dots
Description: Dots is an abstract game of strategy. Score points by lining up the colors. Sounds simple enough, right? Scoring is done 1 for 1, this means one red dot lined up with 2 red dots scores 3 points for the player who layed the piece. There is a twist however; you must subtract the total # of mismatched dots from your score. The more colors you can line up, the more points you earn and the less points you subtract. Its a battle of scoring more positive points than negative points while competing against an opponent who's being extra careful not to set you up for any high scoring opportunities.

Name: Arkham Horror: The Lurker at the Threshold Expansion
Description:
The Lurker at the Threshold is a boxed expansion set for Arkham Horror, the classic cooperative board game for 1-8 players, set in a world of gothic horror created by author H. P. Lovecraft. This expansion will bring new levels of dread to your table top, with the addition of a brand new Herald Sheet for "The Lurker at the Threshold" – a powerful and malevolent being that has appeared to prepare the way for the Ancient One, plus more than 200 components and some extraordinary new game mechanics to boot.

One of the highlights is the full set of 18 Gate markers that are designed to replace those from the Arkham Horror core set, as well as those from The Dunwich Horror and The Kingsport Horror. They are treated exactly the same as the previous Gate markers, except that each Gate now has an additional characteristic. For example, the "Gate of Madness" will cause an investigator to lose one Sanity when they fail to close the Gate, and a "Moving Gate" moves along with monsters during the Mythos phase.
 Brand new to The Lurker at the Threshold are Relationship Cards for use in games with two or more players. Each player draws one Relationship Card at the start of the game, which describes some advantage gained due to how the investigator to your left is related to you. Perhaps you are business associates and mutually reap the benefits of income, or both are Students of the Arcane and gain more frequent access to the Spell deck. No matter how you're related, these will bring a more interesting back-story to your game, involving your characters in more ways than ever before.
 Finally, The Lurker at the Threshold introduces the Dark Pact deck, which will tempt foolish investigators to enter into a terrible arrangement with the Lurker itself. Although these Dark Pacts may grant your investigator enhanced abilities, there is sure to be a cost. What happens when the price is too high?
 Of course, with over 100 new Location cards, Mythos cards, Gate cards and Spells, plus more Common and Unique Items, The Lurker at the Threshold will enhance and expand the enjoyment of Arkham Horror for players of all skill levels.

-- from the publisher's web site, edited slightly to be up-to-date
Families: Series: Arkham Horror Files (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: One Night in Taranto
Description:
One Night in Taranto (makes a bald man humble) is a solitaire game on the attack of the Swordfish of the Royal Navy against the Italian Fleet in the port of Taranto, 11th November 1940. It resulted in serious damages to the ships, without much losses for the British planes. It was a great and bold success.

This game is a simple (4 pages of rules) recreation of that air raid, with a single map and 144 counters.
It plays fast and has a lot of variants, to make it re-playable several time.

Bought by LPS, has been published on the 2011 annual of Against the Odds, with the name of Terrible Swift Swordfish

Name: Alien Panic
Description:
Sci-Fi game version of "CLUE".
Your crew are now on the way home.  But, unfortunately and as you expected from the classic Sci-Fi movie, one of you are parasited by unknown Alien.
You must find out who is the victim and what alien is now in your ship and what room they are now growing before your ship arrive the Earth.

Name: Die Jahreszeiten: Neues Gesellschaftsspiel
Description:
The Seasons - A New Partygame

The gameboard consists of 24 squares, in which one can see symbols of the four seasons, different combinations of dice eyes and the amount to bet.

Rules
The participants put 24 chips in a pot, throw dice in sequence, where everyone sees the plan's winnings or losses in the illustrated squares. Who throws 2 times 6 wins the whole game.

Name: Die Brautsleute
Description:
The bride and groom

At the gameboard one can see ten ovals with people dressed to marry, according to the fashion of the early 19th century in Germany. In the corners one can see dancing couples. In the middle of the gameboard three horses are depicted (Perhaps they are going to pull the wagon with the bride and groom later on!)

Published in Nuremberg, Germany.

Name: Der Deutsche Hanswurst
Description:
The German Harlequin

In the middle of the gameboard one can see the German harlequin and at the borders his 'relatives': Pickelhäring, Jean Potage, Pierrot, Pulcinello, Jack Pudding and Bajazzo.

Published in Nuremberg, Germany.

Name: Das Kleeblatt oder Lumpaci Vagabundus
Description:
The Cloverleaf

The gameboard is divided into 11 squares with pictures of funny characters from the theater: Landjunker, Leim, Zwirn & Knieriem, Dorfbarbier, Staberl, Monostatos, Figaro, Jacob, Papageno, Punpernickel, Matz and Lumpaci Vagabundus.

Published in Nuremberg.

Name: Der Geizige: Ein Spiel
Description:
The covetous

In the middle of the gameboard one can see 'Mr. & Mrs. Covetous' counting money. In eight roundels people are depicted: soldiers, people strolling in the park and people playing music.

Name: Die Schwäne: Ein neues Gesellschafts-Spiel
Description:
In the middle of the gameboard one can see two swans and around 30 squares with information about winning and losing.

Published in Germany.

Name: Die Virtuosen
Description:
The virtuoso

The gameboard consists of a large circle with eleven fields, in which musicians are depicted. Dice are also depicted.

Published in Nuremberg, Germany.

Name: Bean-opoly
Description:
From the Late for the Sky website:

IS THE PLANET SHAKING OR IS IT JUST YOU?

4 out of 5 Americans consume more than 400 million cups of coffee per day! Do we love the bean? Yes we do! We also love the buzz, the taste, the aroma, the ritual...we love everything about the stuff!

BEAN-OPOLY players purchase favorite coffees and paraphernalia then collect Espresso Shots  and trade them in for the Good Buzz. Be the owner of the lowly Drive-Thru Decaf or collect the big rent as the proprietor of The Bean. It’s all fun and games until someone leaves the pot empty and heads straight to NO BUZZ!...does not pass Brew!...does not collect $200!

C’mon! There’s too much blood in your coffee stream! Round up family and friends, put on a pot and gather round the Bean-opoly board.
There’s no such thing as too much of a good thing!

Name: Clue: Secrets in Paris
Description:
You're on a high school drama club tip to France and the sights are like, totally amazing until - OMG! On a dare, a student has stolen a priceless work of art!

Now it's up to you to solve the mystery... one of your classmates is hiding something! Was it White? Did she hide the work of art in the Orsay Museum, using the "rope"? This CLUE game has more secrets, more rumors, more drama than a high school hallway! It's packed with landmarks, scenery, and interesting personalities: including student "passport" profiles, illustrated gameboard, city map CLUE sheets, 9 miniature prop "weapons", Rumor and Intrigue card decks, and more!

Narrow down you suspects, then make your accusation - uncover the mystery that everyone is whispering about.

- From back of box.

This version incorporates the additions from Clue: Discover the Secrets:
Each person has been given a unique power which may be used only once per game. There is an Intrigue deck which may or may not grant a player an extra action. Those Intrigue cards which do not grant an extra action are called Clock Cards. The player who draws the eighth Clock card is eliminated from play. Any player who draws a Clock Card thereafter is also eliminated. The “one” on one of the dice has been replaced by “?”. Any player who rolls “?” must draw an Intrigue card.
Families: Game: Cluedo / Clue (Parker Brothers, et al)

Name: Castle and Cathedral
Description: Through manipulation of influence, bids and bribes, players employ skills provided by the Guilds of medieval Europe to build both a Castle and a Cathedral. The cards represent characters involved in the project, from the Guilds of craftsmen, to the Royalty and Clergy, as well as the Nobility, the Spies, and the Assassins. With the help of a Priest, you might persuade a Guild to abandon an opponent’s project and work for you, but a Guild Master can also turn the tables, wielding great influence among the skilled labor you need to complete your structure.

Name: Baltimore-Opoly
Description:
From the Late for the Sky Website:

We chose some favorite landmarks and traditions, mixed in some crab cakes, great parks, a few festivals, the arts, some BIG FUN... and voilà (vwä lä)-behold; BALTIMORE-OPOLY!
Grab Some Friends and Gather 'Round! Here's a quick idea of how to play! Buy property, collect City Blocks and trade in for a Key to the City. It sounds easy enough - but add in a traffic jam, property taxes, parking tickets and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult... and a lot more FUN!
Get YOUR Game On, Baltimore!
It's Your Roll!

Name: Birmingham-Opoly
Description:
From the Late for the Sky Website:

A board game about the GREAT city of Birmingham! We chose some favorite landmarks and traditions, mixed in some Southern hospitality, great food, a little jazz, the arts, and some BIG FUN...and voilà (vwä lä)-behold; BIRMINGHAM-OPOLY!
Grab Some Friends and Gather 'Round!

Here's a quick idea of how to play!

Buy property, collect City Blocks and trade in for a Key to the City. It sounds easy enough - but add in a traffic jam, property taxes, parking tickets and the IRS and it becomes a little more difficult... and a lot more FUN!

Get YOUR Game On, Birmingham!
It's Your Roll!

Name: Rusalka's Sorrow
Description:
Dark Age Russia is a land full of epic tragegy, mystery and danger. Can you, as the Knyaz (Lord) of a struggling Province lead it to prosperity and overcome the often horrific events that befall you?

Players assume the roles of Lords in a medieval fantasy Russia. They must get the most out of their populations. To aid them they can hire Specialists like Lumberjacks, Heroes, and the dreaded Witch, and construct buildings including some that may bring them glory. In the end, however, it is the player who best deals with the disasters that befall the Lands that will emerge victorious.

The game includes:
1 Actions Board
1 Events Track
4 Player Boards
20 wooden Action Markers
40 Specialist character cards (16 types)
48 Building tiles (12 types)
16 Event Cards (2 decks)

Name: Talisman (Third Edition): Lost Characters
Description:
Games Workshop made a PDF file available for download from the main GW site containing four "Lost" Characters that Jervis Johnson found on a dusty server during one wind-swept evening.

The Characters comprised the Necromancer and Wardancer that had been previously released in White Dwarf magazine #177,  the Ogre which was from White Dwarf magazine #179 and the Pit Fighter which was previously unreleased, but did feature in the playtest version of the game.

The cards feature miniatures taken from GW's large catalogue of games. The Wardancer is the same miniature used in Warhammer Quest: Wardancer and the other miniatures were taken from Mordheim: City of the Damned.

Of note is the fact that the PDF download did not actually have the correct fonts embedded in it, so users had to remake the cards before use.

Name: Midway Island
Description:
The first point of the four pages of its rules' manual says:
"Present Avalon Hill Midway rules (1964) shall apply except where noted, as follows:"
This, for sure, identify this Panzerfaust 53 insert as a Midway expansion. It expands the basic game by adding destroyers, transports, more details and, last but not least, a map of Midway Island and the ground forces that must contend it.
Besides that it remains a product that shows all its age, with a spartan graphics, the best that could do, in 1972, a semi-homemade magazine like it was Panzerfaust in that period.
The result is the best that could have been made by R.W. Garbisch with what could allow a magazine like Panzerfaust in 1972.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Bloody Steppes of Crimea: Alma – Balaclava – Inkerman 1854
Description:
Tactical game about three famous battles of Crimean War.

Game scale:
1 hex = 200 m (Alma 250 m)
1 game turn = 30 minutes
1 counter = infantry battalion-riffle company/cavalry regiment/artillery battery.

Game description

The game uses the standard hex-and-counter system, and ten-sided dice. Each hex represents 200 metres or 218 yards of terrain (Alma 250 metres or 273 yards), each game turn corresponds to 20-30 minutes of real time.

Infantry is represented by battalions and light infantry companies, cavalry by regiments (sometimes divided into two counters), artillery by batteries (classified by weight).

Each game turn is divided into phases:
1)Command phase – players use their Commanders-in-Chief and dispatch riders to give orders to subordinate commanders.
2)Activation phase – after determining the initiative, players, using the Activation Markers, choose the division to activate. Activated units, move, fire, commence melee combat and reorganise disorganised units. The opponent can react by firing or counterattacking
3)Reorganisation phase – players reorganise broken units

The principle of the game is based on an order system, which is associated with target hexes. The player must carry out the assigned order (of course, he gives them to himself), until the order is changed by the Commander-in-Chief, or the division commander manages to change it by himself. The order must be associated with a target hex (i.e attack hex, defend hex). The possible orders are: ATTACK, DEFEND, FORCED MARCH.

The game tries to present the diversity of combatants tactics mainly through unit formations. And so – Russian infantry can fight in company or closed columns, French infantry in closed columns or lines and the British infantry only in lines. Each side can form squares, and can use skirmishers. The French Eastern Army excels in light infantry tactics due to it’s many formations of such units (chasseurs, zouaves, algerian tiraillieurs).

The game treats the concept of  zone of control differently from other games – it gives up the obligation to stop moving the unit in the enemy ZOC. The ZOC is a phenomenon that allows to fire or initiate close combat, and it is dependent on the units formation and the range of its firearms.

Unit movement doesn’t differ from other hex-and-counter systems.

The game discerns fire combat and melee combat. The fire combat takes into consideration the following aspects:
1)firing unit strength
2)firing unit formation (skirmishers)
3)target formation
4)distance to target

Fire combat is initiated at the cost of movement points in the unit’s activation phase, and once as a reaction for the enemy’s doings. Fire combat is based on the unit’s morale modifier, which is a combination of unit’s morale, training and other “psychological” factors. Fire combat effects in loss of  endurance, disorganisation and in critical cases, breaking of the attacked unit. Losing movement point is also the effect of fire combat.

Artillery fire combat is constructed similarly to infantry fire combat – it only takes into account the differences in range and firepower of guns.

As a rule, to initiate melee combat, the unit must fight in a compact formation (column, line) or be a cavalry unit. Starting combat requires for a attacking unit to posses sufficient movement points after moving (a marker is placed, on the unit that meets that condition). Melee combat is also based on the unit’s morale, strength, formation, also the terrain and attacks from the flank or the unit’s rear. Effects of melee combat are disorganisation (also of the attacking unit) or breakdown and taking flight. Cavalry combat also includes the unit’s momentum – which is taken from the type of the unit (heavy, lancers, light cavalry). Cavalry may react by counter-charging.

The loss of unit’s endurance during the game is marked on special tables. The use of tables intents to show precisely the diverse levels of combat losses.

Name: PODS
Description:
PODS is a game for 2 players.
There is not enough place for every Pods in the cavern ... Try to place your own Pods and beware of your opponents feet.

Pods are tiny animals, living in the darkness of unknown caverns. They are made of a head and some feet  (bipod have 2 feet, tripod: 3 ... octopod:8). A foot may be small: a foot for walking (controls 1 square forward) or big: a foot for running (controls the aligned squares forward).

Players alternate turns and place their pods in the cavern (a 7x7 grid) but have to deal with the Pods 'way of life': respect your opponent tiny space. So each foot of any pod can never threat a square occupied by an enemy pod. When a player is unable to enter a new pod in the cavern, he loses the game.

In the advanced rules, the pods may move on the board an threat their enemies ... if a pod has no longer a foot able to walk, he dies and is removed from the board. Players then have to enter their 14 pods into the cavern to win.

Name: Spouse-ology
Description:
Because you're my favorite subject!

Spouse-ology challenges husbands to think like their wives and vice versa. While competing against other couples, your spouse will guess how you would answer questions from five different categories. You'll love scoring extra credit points while you and your spouse do wacky stunts together. If you mismatch answers on certain questions, you and your spouse will have to do a fun penalty. Watch out you could be in a 30-second lip lock! Spouse-ology is an excellent ice-breaker or celebration for a couple's small group!

For 2-6 married couples.

(from the publisher's website)

Name: Pola-rink
Description:
Magnetic ice hockey game, very similar to the Balyna Super Soccer game produced by Balyna (Toogood and Jones of Whitstable in Kent) in the United Kingdom during the 1950s.

Game consists of:

- playing board
- four adjustable plastic legs to be inserted at each corner of the board
- two plastic goals
- four wooden playing rods with a magnet at the end, two each of red and blue
- ten plastic players with magnets on their bases, usually 5 red and 5 blue players
- a small wooden puck
- rules

Each player has a magnet on the bottom of its base, which was manipulated by a rod (with a magnet on the end of it) which went under the table. The magnets of each team are polarised in reverse, so you cannot affect your opponents players with your rod. The rod is used to drag your players across the board, thus allowing you to push the puck around.

The game board is a smooth hardboard surface, marked out with an ice hockey pitch, and a basic raised surround to stop the puck going out of play.

Good fun - lots frantic action!

Name: Armageddon Hour
Description:
Armageddon Hour is a solo boardgame that pits your character, the mutant hunter Frazer, against a horde of mutants. You have a gun, limited ammo and one hour of time to storm a mutant hideout and kill the mutant boss before he sets off a bomb. You play with a stopwatch or a chess timer, and have exactly one hour of real time to finish the game. If you don’t complete your mission in time, the bomb explodes and you lose!

The pdf edition includes a rulebook (color and inksaving versions), paper figures, 27 equipment cards, 9 skill cards, 9 profile cards, 1 profile sheet and 6 flooplans. Just print them out, cut them out and add dice! You’ll need at least 4 six-sided (regular) dice to play this game, and a watch.

Rules by Ganesha Games, floorplans by Paper Make IT!, and paper miniatures by One Monk.

Floorplans can be edited and modified by Shuffler (not included): source smp files are here included to expand and enhance your experience and increase the longevity of Armageddon Hour. 
 (*from the PaperMakeIt.com website)

Name: Grand Jeu de L'Histoire Ancienne de la Grèce
Description: A roll and move game from 1 to 63. The whole board game is full of depictions from the Greece history.

Name: Spiel verschiedener natürlicher Gegenstände and der grossen Kette der Welt
Description: A roll and move game, played in a chain numbered from 1 to 85. In these fields one can see: animals, flowers and other depictions. In the middle of the gameboard a tempietto, a small commemorative martyrium, is depicted.

Name: Der Freischütz: Ein Gesellschafts-Spiel
Description:
The Marksman or The Freeshooter

A roll and move game played from number 1 to 64. The depictions are from the opera 'Der Freischütz' by Carl Maria von Weber (1786– 1826). A very beautiful boardgame!

Name: 3 Stooges
Description:
3 Stooges is a 2 player game played on a 6x5 grid of squares, with three cells removed in its of its corners, resulting in a diamond-shaped playing area.  Black and white stacking pieces are used; to start the game, the pieces are laid out one to each cell, alternating black and white across the board, but for the long center row of six cells, each of which has two stacked pieces of its color.

On every turn, each player may do one of the following:

     Swap the places of any two single, unstacked stones, of either color.
        Ko rule - The player cannot swap a stone swapped in the opponent's last move.
        Ko rule - After two consecutive swaps, it's illegal to swap again.
    
     Move the upper stone (from a friendly stack of two stones) to an adjacent (orthogonal or diagonal) cell occupied by an isolated friendly stone.


To win, a player must line up three stacks of his own color in a row, orthogonal or diagonal, or stalemate his opponent.

Name: Un
Description:
Un is a 2 player game played on a 5x5 hexagonal board.
One player drops the neutral stone on a cell and the other chooses who starts.
On each turn,each player slides the neutral stone a number of empty cells in a straight line and each cell passed becomes unavailable for the rest of the game.
The first player that cannot move loses.

Name: Das Grosse Ziel
Description:
The big goal

A game about life. It starts with birth and ends with death.

Published in Germany.

Name: Golgo Island
Description:
From the Wargamedownloads.com site

Golgo Island is a fast-paced Pulp/Mulp game built around the WarEngine system (previously incarnated in ShockForce and GWAR: Rumble in Antarctica by DemonBlade games) aimed at bringing all kind of over-the-top action focusing on Pulp or B-Movies heroes to your tabletop for fast-paced, tongue in the cheek games.

Gangsters, kung-fu, sci-fi, horror - any genre that involves heroes rivaling in unbelievable feats against hordes of helpless villains or apparently undefeatable adversity can be played in the loose and convenient setting of a lost, out of time island where everything is possible and any approximation will be forgiven . As it that can do more can do less, the rules can be used for a melting pot of the above or any of them specifically, so the Golgo Island rules can be used for anything from the ever popular zombie games to treasure hunting among many other things.

Golgo Island offers fast and intuitive play, alternate unit activation,
game balance guided by a point system, and completely adaptable scenarios and game conditions that require neither an umpire, a game master, or even charts to look up all you need is a copy of these rules, a handful of miniatures, some six-sided dice (D6’s), a tape measure and a roughly 3’ x 3’ playing area. Thanks to simple yet dynamic game mechanics, heroes and henchmen face player and non-player opponents as  well as (more or less) random events in non-stop action and pass-me-the-pop-corn atmosphere. The amount of details and non-player intervention can be tailored out depending on your scenario’s requirements and the number of players involved, so while the game is best played with up to 4 players you can easily enjoy it with many more of them on board!

Contents:

     The compiled WarEngine and Golgo Island' rules.
     Background on Golgo Island and its denizens.
     Profiles for over 60 ready-to-play characters and henchmen.
     A profile builder section, complete with special powers, traits, and a point value system, to help you create your own balanced yet characterful profiles.
     7 scenarios, and scenario special rules and guidelines to help you adapt them to your needs and imagination.
     and more!

Name: Die Blumenlust oder Floras Tempel: Ein neues Würfelspiel
Description: A roll and move game from number 1 to 40. In each field flowers, animals and garden equipments are depicted. In the middle a temple is depicted. In the corners of the gameboard one can see children working in gardens.

Name: Neues Jagdspiel
Description: A roll and move game from 1 to 45. In the round fields one can see  hunting scenes and in the corners hunters.

Name: Talisman (4th Edition): Optional Characters
Description:
Following the release of Talisman: Revised 4th Edition, Black Industries made a PDF available via their website which featured three optional Characters for the game.

These characters were rehashes of ones found in the 2nd Edition of Talisman using artwork taken from Adventure cards in the latest release.

The Gnome artwork was taken from the Adventure card of the same name, and the Character was based on the Leprechaun originally included in the Talisman: Expansion Set.

The Hobgoblin artwork was taken from the Adventure card of the same name, and the Character was based on the Hobgoblin originally included in the Talisman: Expansion Set.

The Pixie artwork was taken from the Fairy Adventure card, and the Character was based on the Sprite originally included in the 2nd edition The Talisman Dungeon.

One thing to note is that the Pixie character was originally to be a Nixie and use artwork from the Imp Adventure card, but it was thought that this looked a bit too evil!

Name: Die Spassvögel und die Glücksvögel: Ein kurzweiliges Gesellschaftspiel
Description:
The funbird and the fortunebird

A game from number 1 to 18. In the square one can see depictions of birds and other items. At the goal, number 18, a stork and a baby are depicted.

Published in Nuremberg.

Name: Robinsons Reisen zu Wasser und zu Lande, so wie seine Schicksale auf der durch ihn allgemein bekannten wüsten Insel
Description:
Robinsons Reisen zu Wasser und zu Lande, so wie seine Schicksale auf der durch ihn allgemein bekannten wüsten Insel - Ein neues und höchst interessantes Post- und Reisespiel zugleich als Bildgalerie zu Campes Robinson, und als Stoff zu belehrenden Gesprächen über Natur- und Völker- kunde nutzbar mit deutlicher Erklärung des Spiels und einer Cassentabelle

A roll and move game based on 'The Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe of York, Mariner: Who lived Eight and Twenty Years, all alone in an un-inhabited Island on the coast of America, near the Mouth of the Great River of Oroonoque; Having been cast on Shore by Shipwreck, where-in all the Men perished but himself. With An Account how he was at last as strangely deliver'd by Pyrates. Written by Himself, or simply Robinson Crusoe, is a novel by Daniel Defoe.' A roll and move game from number 1 to 80.

Published in Dresden.

Name: Flames of War: A Bridge Too Far – The Battles for Oosterbeek and Arnhem
Description:
A Bridge Too Far is a supplement for the World War II miniatures game Flames of War. It covers the battles for Oosterbeek and Arnhem during Operation Market Garden, September 1944.

The book contains a brief history of the operation, maps, and army lists for the British 1st Airborne Division, the Polish paratroopers and German kampfgruppen.

A Bridge to Far is softcover book with 80 full-color pages.

Name: Norderneyer Spiel oder die Reisse in's Seebad
Description:
The Nordeneyer Game or the travel to the Seaside Resort

A roll and move game from number 1 to 39. In the squares one can see depictions of the life at the coast in summer.


     Norderneyer Seegat connects the North Sea and the Wattenmeer between the East Friesian Islands of Juist and Norderney.

Name: Die Reise nach den Pyramiden
Description: A roll and move game from number 1 to 21. At the gameboard one can see depictions from different parts of Egypt. Rules in German and French. Published in Germany.

Name: Der Hühnerhof
Description:
A roll and move game played from number 1 to 73. All depictions are from the hen run.

Published in Nuremberg.

Name: Robinson
Description:
A roll and move game based on 'The Life and Strange Surprizing Adventures of Robinson Crusoe of York, Mariner: Who lived Eight and Twenty Years, all alone in an un-inhabited Island on the coast of America, near the Mouth of the Great River of Oroonoque; Having been cast on Shore by Shipwreck, where-in all the Men perished but himself. With An Account how he was at last as strangely deliver'd by Pyrates. Written by Himself, or simply Robinson Crusoe, is a novel by Daniel Defoe.' You play the game from number 1 to 30.

Published in Mainz, Germany.

Name: Neuestes Ritter- Turnier- und Sarazenen-Spiel
Description: A roll and move game played from number 1 to 94. At the gameboard one can see depictions of the life of a knight.

Name: Fire Trivia Game
Description:
Similar to Trivial Pursuit but with a questions regarding fire.  The object of the game is to successfully obtain a full set of six pawns (one from each category) to "man" your fire engine, then proceed to the center of the board and answera question to "put out the fire".  The categories are:
Fire Apparatus
Tactics
Safety
Industrial Fire Protection
General Fire Service
Building Construction

Name: Die Englische Parforce-Jagd
Description:
An English Chase on Horseback

A race game, where the gameboard has five tracks, 12 squares long. You race with a hunter, a dog or a deer. Rules in four languages.

Published in Germany.

Name: TowerRun
Description:
TowerRun is a standard issue Open License Print and Play Dungeon Crawl Adventure Game for 1 (solo) to 4 players. It attempts to make use of several distinguishing mechanics.

First, no DM player is required. All monsters obey simple AI/automatic rules, which can be performed by anybody willing to do it. Second, dungeon crawl games often take a very long time to play due to a lot of dice rolling. TowerRun attempts to minimize this by eliminating dice rolling wherever possible, including during combat. The (hopeful) end result is not only a faster game, but a more strategic method of play. Third, there is a built in “score” system that single or multiple players can attempt to beat whenever they play. The game is not designed to be “beaten” on the first attempt, so multiple attempts are necessary, and each time you can try and beat your previous high score. Finally, a core mechanic of the game revolves around random pairings of objects and enchantments. Quite often objects have unknown enchantments that can be revealed in a calculated or risky method. Players do not know what the enchantments are until they use the item, but if they use the item without first identifying it they run the risk of it being cursed.

These mechanics make for heightened tension, faster game play, and a depth of balance and strategy.

Name: The Wogglebug Game of Conundrums
Description:
The Wogglebug Game of Conundrums. Salem, Mass.: Parker Bros., Inc., 1905.

The Wogglebug Game of Conundrums is a formalized guessing game, a contest of wit and skill in which players take turns asking riddles. The player that cannot answer loses.

The "What Did the Woggle-Bug Say? Contest" made this Oz character a household name and inspired all kinds of novelties. That was the beginning of a "Woggle-Bug" craze.

Parker Brothers quickly produced their own tie-in for the hype, introducing The Wogglebug Game of Conundrums the same year. The Wogglebug Game of Conundrums is a game of riddles (none having to do with Oz) produced in 1905.

This is the first toy connected to the Land of Oz as it predates The Wonderful Game of OZ. This unauthorized novelty was only in production for a short time, and is the oldest Oz toy to be found.

Neither Baum nor his book The Marvelous Land of Oz (1904) are mentioned anywhere on this game.

The complete game consisted of a chromolithographed box containing a set of 51 gray colored Conundrum cards and 51 buff-colored Answer cards with one page "Rules for Playing The Woggle Bug Game" and Parker Bros. flyer for two other card games, Pit and Quit .

Sampled below are some of the Woggle Bug's silly questions, and the corresponding answer cards for the game. Popular Culture themes of the time were referenced, as seen in the answer to "What was Adam's favorite popular song?"

Some examples of the Conundrums (questions relying for their effects on punning in either the question or the answer) are:

 Why didn't the dog want to go into the Ark?
Because he had a bark of his own.

With what would you fill a barrel to make it lighter than when it was empty?
Holes.

What was Adam's favorite popular song?
"There's only one girl in the world for me."

What kind of medicine does the iceman take?
Pond's extract.

It is unfortunate that the colorful design of the box cover did not extend to the playing cards. 
As this was an unauthorized game, Parker Brothers might have found it too difficult to reproduce Neill's stylish illustrations past the images of the Woggle-Bug and Jack Pumpkinhead on the box cover.

The earliest toy associated with Oz and one of the rarest examples of Oziana.

Name: 10-4 Good Buddy: The CB Game
Description: Roll and move track movement game centered around the good ole fashioned Citizen's Band radio.

Name: Race to Pooh Corner
Description:
User Summary...

Spin and move game with a colorful game board and 3D trees.

Name: Talisman (Third Edition): Game Trade Magazine #37 Characters
Description:
As part of an advertising feature for the reprinted version of Talisman (Third Edition) in 2003, Games Trade Magazine (a publication of Alliance Distributors) published two Characters for the game.

These Characters were the Vampire and Swordsman.

The cards featured miniatures taken from GW's tabletop game, Mordheim: City of the Damned.

The Vampire and Swordsman had previously been released in GW's house magazine, White Dwarf #186.

The Thief from White Dwarf #177 and the Dark Elf from White Dwarf #179 were due to printed in the next issue of Games Trade Magazine, but due to constraints of space this did not happen.

Name: Talisman (Third Edition): White Dwarf UK #186/US #185 Characters
Description:
In the run up to the release of the Talisman (Third Edition): Dragon's Tower, Games Workshop released two new Characters as part of an advertising feature in their house magazine, White Dwarf #186 in the UK, and White Dwarf #185 in North America.

These Characters were the Vampire and Swordsman.

The cards featured miniatures taken from GW's tabletop game, Warhammer.

The Vampire and Swordsman were released again in 2003 as part of an advertising feature for the reprinted version of Talisman (Third Edition).

Name: Talisman (Third Edition): White Dwarf #179 Characters
Description:
In the run up to the release of the Talisman (Third Edition): City of Adventure, Games Workshop released two new Characters as part of an advertising feature in their house magazine, White Dwarf #179.

These Characters were the Ogre and Dark Elf.

The cards featured miniatures taken from GW's tabletop game, Warhammer.

The Ogre was released again in 2002 as part of the Talisman (Third Edition): Lost Characters PDF on the GW website.

Name: Talisman (Third Edition): White Dwarf #177 Characters
Description:
In the run up to the release of the Talisman (Third Edition): Dungeon of Doom, Games Workshop released four new Characters as part of an advertising feature in their house magazine, White Dwarf #177.

These Characters were the Thief, Necromancer, Wardancer and Dragon Rider.

The Characters were also printed in the French language edition of White Dwarf #14 when the Talisman (Third Edition): Dungeon of Doom was released in France as Royaumes Du Mal.

The cards featured miniatures taken from GW's tabletop game, Warhammer.

The Necromancer and Wardancer were released again in 2002 as part of the Talisman (Third Edition): Lost Characters PDF on the GW website.

Name: The Jewel in the Crown
Description:
In the run up to the release of the Talisman: Expansion Set and following the release of the 2nd Edition of Talisman, Games Workshop released a number of new cards as part of an advertising feature in their house magazine, White Dwarf #72.

These cards comprised the Samurai Character, Curfew & Closed Shop Adventure cards and Bolster, Transmute, Bladesharp, Resurrection & Enrich Spells.

The Samurai was later officially released as part of the Talisman: The Adventure expansion.

Resurrection and Transmute were later released in the French language publication, Le Héraut Citadel #4.

Name: Talisman (Second Edition): White Dwarf #115 Cards
Description:
In the run up to the release of the Talisman City for the 2nd Edition of Talisman, Games Workshop released a number of new cards as part of an advertising feature in their house magazine, White Dwarf #115.

These cards consisted of 4 "trigger" and associated Master Level Character cards -

The Champion of Chaos Adventure card and Champion of Chaos Character.

The Recruiter Adventure card and the Templar Character.

The Noble Adventure card and the Herald Character.

The Way of the Lotus Spell and the Mystic Character.

These cards were later reprinted in the Polish language publication, Magia i Miecz #4/93.

Name: Word Bank
Description:
User Summary...

An Anagrams style game of moving around the board and spelling words.

Name: Talisman 2nd Edition: Le Héraut Citadel #4 Cards
Description:
As part of an advertising feature for the 2nd Edition of Talisman, the French hobby magazine, Le Héraut Citadel (The Citadel Herald), which was a magazine like the Citadel Journal, released a set of cards in French for the game, in Issue #4.

The cards comprised the Résurrection, Transmutation,  Faiblesse, Débilité & Amitié Spells and Piège, Lance-Feu des Skaven,  Chaos, Troglodyte & Roi Crapaud Adventure cards.

(* Resurrection, Transmute, Weakness, Feeble Mind, Friendship, Trap, Skaven Flamethrower, Chaos, Troglodyte and Toad King!)

Resurrection and Transmute had already appeared in Issue #72 of White Dwarf magazine, however Weakness and Feeble Mind appeared later as part of Talisman City.

Name: Talisman (Second Edition): Le Héraut Citadel #2 Cards
Description:
As part of an advertising feature for the 2nd Edition of Talisman, the French hobby magazine, Le Héraut Citadel (The Citadel Herald), which was a magazine like the Citadel Journal, released a set of cards in French for the game, in Issue #2.

The cards comprised the Skaven & Héraut Characters and Clé, Pillard, Hydra & Lyre Adventure cards.

(* Skaven, Herald, Key, Plunderer, Hydra and Lyre!)

Name: Riches 'n Rascals
Description:
Discover the wonders of the ancient world in a cut-throat board game of piracy, trading and treasure.

Boats laden with gold, diamonds and great treasure, sail the Seven Seas in Riches 'n Rascals - grappling with pirates and encountering wonderous and momentous moments in world history.
You begin your journey in the biting cold of the Ice Age, a time when terrifying sabre toothed tigers and mighty mammoths roam ice covered lands.  As you sail the seas trading and pirating, you travel through the ages encountering the invention of the wheel, the great pyramids, Tutankhamen's magnificent mask and other great human achievements.
Can you fill your treasure chest with the most loot through cunning trading and pirating? 
A cut-throat game of adventure and intrigue, Riches 'n Rascals is an exciting educational game where players discover world history without any background knowledge.  No two games are exactly the same, enabling players to play indefinitely, discovering more & more about world history.

How Riches 'n Rascals is played:
On your turn you roll the two dice (a numbered die and ‘scroll’ die) and move your boat counter filed with gold, diamonds or other treasure to lands near and far.  You trade with other lands at their home port and pirate other players by landing on their boats.  If a ‘scroll’ die is rolled, you consult the ‘History Scrolls’ - read out what is happening in this place and time in history and follow the Scrolls’ instructions.  If great achievements are happening in history you may get to double your loot or have a second turn, if there is strife - you may lose your loot or miss a turn.  Any loot you safely bring back to your home port can be placed in your Treasure Chest where it is safe from all pirating.

Name: Fish Links
Description:
From the game box:

Get into the swim with this exciting water game that's fun for the whole family! Players throw their fishing lines into the water and try to catch the colorful sea animals with their fishing rods. For added fun, sea animals also link to each other so you can catch a bunch in one try. The player who catches the most sea animals wins!

Components:
2 fishing rods, 10 assorted sea animals (2 goldfish, 2 sharks, 2 octopus, 2 starfish and 2 lobsters). The animals float to allow for play in or out of water. The sea animals are placed in between the two players.

There are four ways to play:

For younger players - both players try to fish for the sea animals at the same time. They must hook an animal with the fishing rod and bring it out of the water in order to retrieve it. The player who collects the most animals wins.

For older players:

Links - players fish for the sea animals, trying to link as many of them as possible until all have been collected. The player with the most sea animals linked together wins.

Collect-A-Set - players fish, trying to catch one of every type of sea animal. The first player to collect a complete set wins.

High Score - some sea animals are easier to catch than others because they have more arms, legs, tails and fins. Each animal has a different point value: starfish & octopus are worth 5 points; goldfish & shark are worth 10 points; lobster is worth 20 points. The player with the most points when all animals have been collected wins.

Name: Attacke
Description:
Attacke belongs to the "Taschen-Spiele"("pocket games") series from Heyne which included 34 games.

The board shows a small castle on one side of the board, which the defender must try to defend against the attacks from the attacker. Both players have just one single playing piece for their regular moves. The rest of the playing pieces (34 chips for the defender, 2 tokens for the attacker) are used to keep track of the movement limitations of the players: while the attacker can use every path outside the castle only once, the defender cannot use the same path within the castle more than two subsequent turns.

If the attacker manages to enter the castle exactly on the point where the defender is staying, he is the winner. If he is forced to enter the castle on an empty point, he has lost the game, because the defender will catch him on his next turn. The attacker has also lost the game, if he has no possible move left (outside of the castle).

The game exists in 2 editions with different rules. According to the designer Tom Werneck, the first edition had the problem, that the attacker won in most cases, but the second edition did not help this game from being broken, because now, the defender won most times!

Name: Squares
Description:
Another implementation of the traditional game of Dots and Boxes.  In this instance, the game plays out on a cross-shaped board.  On a player's turn that player adds a "fence" to the board.  Whenever a player's fence-play finishes a full square around a box, that player claims the box with a token.  The game continues until there are no further moves, and the player who has claimed the most boxes wins.

Similar to the game Boxes.

Name: Kaeru
Description:
Players move a team of three frogs of different speed-determining sizes from waterlily to waterlily to try and capture more and bigger prey than their opponent.

This game uses Icehouse Pieces and a deck of Aquarius.

Name: Icebreaker, rompe el hielo
Description:
Desde las reglas:
Como cualquier otra noche de fin de semana, tienes un objetivo en mente: LIGAR. Y como en la realidad, no te será fácil, tendrás que usar tu encanto personal y para que resulte realmente efectivo, algún  que otro regalillo para conquistar a ese/a chico/a con el que te has cruzado en la discoteca.

Por medio de los dados podrás moverte por el tablero para ir entrando en las casillas de tienda, donde comprar objetos, para tu pareja.
El tiempo es limitado, pudiendo variar de entre 15 a 45 minutos, por lo que tienes que darte prisa en conquistar a esa chica o chico antes que los demás.
Un tablero modulable para que cada partida sea única.
Tu objetivo, conseguir 20 puntos para besar a tu personaje.
Ocho personajes que conseguir ligarte, con características únicas.
Más de 40 objetos divididos entre 10 tiendas para elegir.
Y para más diversión, las "Putadas de Calle", cartas para complicarte un poco más conseguir tu reto.

From the rules:
Like anyother night on weekend, your aim in mind is: Get off with sombody. And actually, it isn't going to be easy. You must use your personal charm and, to make it realy effective, some gifts to conquer that boy or girl yoy found in the disco.

Using dice you must run across the board, going into the shops to buy objects to conquer that boy or girl before anyonelse.
Be fast, your time is limited and the other players are going to try to win too.
A modulable board to make every play different.
Your objective, score 20 points to kiss your objective. 
8 different characters to kiss, each one with different 
characteristics.
More than 40 objects dividen into 10 shops to choose.
And if you need more fun, the "Street Shits" to make harder your goal.

Name: Conni kommt in die Schule
Description:
A game collection with 4 learning games, age 5-7.

Common gameplay: The player rolls a die, moves the Conni figure that number of spaces on the board, and tries to solve the task on the target space. If he succeeds, he gets a part of a "Schultüte" (First-Day-Of-School-Surprise-Bag). The player(s) who first collect all 5 pieces win the game.

The tasks are suited for first graders: adding and subtracting numbers up to 10 (or 20); searching for the starting letter of an item; memory variants with letters, items, and numbers.

Name: XtraHeart
Description:
From the website: 
"A game of Super Heroes with Chess like strategies. 
You can play many combinations of Heroes and Powers, and in each game you can combine different heroes with different Side Kicks".

XtraHeart is a two player card game. Each player controls three home base zones where they secretly place their Headquarters and two Auxiliary bases. Players attempt to occupy their opponent's Headquarters or both of their Auxiliary bases to win the game.
The cards consist of Heroes, Side Kicks and Powers cards. Players build combinations of these cards and move out in to one of the three central outer space zones in order to battle their opponent's card combinations.

Name: Circle's Winner
Description:
Are you more cunning, devious and brilliant than your friends?  Are you sure?

Now you can prove it...

You only know the identity of one piece on the board - yours.  And your goal is to simply move the piece to the center circle before any of your opponents pieces reach there first.  But wait, not so fast.  If anyone finds out which piece is yours you're sure to lose!

A simple game with simple rules; yet requiring a not-so-simple strategy of guile and cunning to win.

Practically the easiest "print and play" game possible.  Just print, scrounge up some unique pieces (or cut out the ones provided) and you're ready to play.  ->  SEE THE FILE BELOW


    Note: At present only the basic board is uploaded. Additional boards with unique scoring systems will be added later.

Name: Master and Commander
Description:
Master and Commander is a print'n'play game of 18th century naval combat.  Players will maneuver their sailing ships in a hex grid sea in an effort to cross their opponents T (naval lingo for getting into a good firing position), or even board and capture an enemy vessel to use it against him.  Victory is achieved by either sinking all enemy ships or chasing them out of the sea.  Rules allow for changing wind conditions, crew quality, and shore  batteries.

The game includes  six pages of rules, double-sided counters for 40 ships, and two sheets of hex grid.

Master and Commander is a fast-play simulation of Napoleonic sea combat. Release 2.0 expands the beautiful counter set created by Tom Cundiff, adds rules for crew quality and provides hexagonal grid templates for map creation.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Interpol Calling
Description: From the game cover: Enthralling game of international intrigue, based on the fascinating exciting television series from the 1950's starring Charles Korvin as Paul Duval. Pursuit of criminals  by international police throughout many countries of the world.

Name: Gate
Description:
A Chinese checkers-like game where a player has to bring one of his stones to the opposite corner of the board.

Stones move by going through special "gates" from one board cell to another. Once a stone goes through a "gate", the "gate" turns 90 degrees so it connects a different pair of board cells.

A player can also win the game by leaving the opponent without possible moves.

Name: Hydro Lord
Description:
From the rules introduction.
You are broke and have never succeeded financially.  This time however it is going to be different, you manage to save a handful of dollars and decide to exit the rat race.  You begin by investing in a business set-up; four months later you reap the rewards.  Things are going smoothly, the money starts to roll in when suddenly your mates see a chopper overhead; but you are too late.  Your business set-up is raided. This is one of the many scenarios that may happen to you.
Be captivated by sheer exhilaration as the game takes hold and catapults you into the secret lives of the pursued.
The winner is the player who at the end of the game, becomes Hydro Lord.  Good luck.

Name: Emmerdale DVD Game
Description:
Test your knowledge of ITV's longest running and most popular soap opera, Emmerdale. A fun quiz for the whole family, the game features more than 700 questions and classic clips from the show, with an emphasis on the contemporary storylines.

Choose from a selection of characters, but beware who you choose because there are forfeits for bad behaviour!
Multiple choice, time-based, questions based around clips, stills and storylines from the '70s to the current incarnation
6 categories of question: Families, workplace, romance, the Woolpack, feuds and friendship
'Superfan' section to test the real addicts!

Contents:
DVD Game
12 'Bar Quiz' Style Beer Mats

Name: Original Scala
Description:
From the back of the Box (translated from German):

An exciting puzzle game for 2 to 4 players. The players try place down five of their own pieces in a row, while preventing the other players from doing the same.

Name: Hakkefuda
Description:
ï¼¨ï½ï½‹ï½‹ï½…fuda is a Japanese game based on the Yi Jing (I Ching) Ba Gua (Pa Kua) figures.

The box contains 139 cards total and includes a deck of 8x8 trigrams and all 64 hexgrams of the Yi Jing series. Each deck includes two blank cards. There are seven reference cards included for the games playable with the two decks. A small gameboard is included.

From the back of the box, translated from Japanese:

'Hakkefuda is a set of original game cards that takes for its motif the eight trigrams (Gua) used in fortune telling and Feng Shui. It is possible to play several card and Hanafuda style games.

"Gua" were invented in Ancient China, representing all things and phenomena through the two fundamental ideas of yin and yang, one could say they are the first digital inscriptions. The Ba Gua represent the fundamental attributes of all things through three yin-yang lines: they represent "heaven", "earth", "thunder", "wind", "water", "fire", "mountain", and "spring".'

The box contains rules for three games, entitled "Taikoubou" (å¤ªå…¬æœ› - The Great Duke's Hope), "Houshinhakkejin"(å°ç¥žå…«å¦é™£ - Signet God Ba Gua Formation), and "Hakkaken"(å…«å¦å‰£ - Ba Gua Sword)

Name: World's Greatest Villain
Description:
So, you want to be a villain? The best? In Century City, it's not so easy. You've got to gain reputation, find gear, and plot nefarious schemes. Note of warning, though – trust no one. Villains don't share, and a host of others will stand in your way. Overcome these obstacles, though, and you can establish yourself as the greatest criminal mind of all time!

World's Greatest Villain is a fast-paced, competitive card game. Collect and equip gear, complete schemes, sabotage your opponents as you gain reputation, all so you can establish yourself as the top in your profession.

World's Greatest Villain is designed for 3-6 players, ages 12 and up.

Name: Professor Noggin's Wonders of the World
Description:
Professor Noggin's 34th education card game teaches children ages 7 and up about awe inspiring landmarks from different cultures and different times. Game comes with 30 cards, one die, and instructions.

List of card topics include skyscrapers, dams, bridges, seven wonders of the ancient world, pyramids, monuments, and more.

Name: Munchkin Fairy Dust Handbag Of Holding
Description:
User SummaryThe Handbag of Holding was a promotional item originally given away by Steve Jackson Games during the August 2009 Gen Con in Indianapolis. It was reprinted in February 2012 and given away to people who spent $75 or more at the publisher's online store. Starting on March 6th, 2012 it briefly became available for purchase at the online store. So what had once been a highly collectible item due to its rarity, was now just another piece of Munchkin merchandise.

The handbag is a standard handbag, colored pink and with a picture of the Sparkly Good Fairy from the Munchkin Fairy Dust booster pack. As a handbag, it's nothing exceptional, but it also comes with a special rule for use in any Munchkin card game that includes the Munchkin Fairy Dust expansion. The rule allows you to take a card from the Fairy Dust deck's discard pile, once per game (see the corresponding board game version for details).

Part of the Munchkin series

Name: All About Raleigh, North Carolina
Description: Like other "All About Town" game, learn all about Raleigh, North Carolina (in 1982) with this "Exciting, Fast Moving Game for the Entire Family." The largish 6-piece board shows the major streets of downtown with businesses at the appropriate locations. The object is to travel on the playing board to the shopping locations shown on your Shopping List.

Name: Classic BattleTech: Technical Readout 3075
Description:
In November 3067 the Second Star League disbanded. The Word of Blake - a splinter group of ComStar - had been on the verge of joining in fulfillment of ancient prophecies. Denied their dream, the Blakists sought to preserve the Star League against the follies of the Houses, but its fanaticism manifested this noble goal as the Jihad: a horrific war that has pitted every faction against each other and even themselves. Against such an anvil, new cutting edge machines of war are marched into the fire. The discovery of an ancient Hegemony Memory Core graphically showcases the desperation of the conflict, as primitive 'Mechs not seen on a battlefield since the dawn of 'Mech production over half a millennia ago once again appear.

Classic BattleTech Technical Readout: 3075 provides a comprehensive look at the latest machines of war debuting during the Jihad: from 'Mechs to battle armor, Support Vehicles to DropShips and more. In addition, a complete "Age of War" section covers the Terran Hegemony and each of the five Great Houses during the Age of War, including the very first BattleMechs produced by each faction and how such machines are starting to appear once more. Each military vehicle is illustrated in detail, accompanied by a description of its history, capabilities, game stats, and some of the unit's most famous pilots.

Name: Level II
Description:
Level II is a fast paced skirmish miniatures game, set in the future.
In the year 2222 mankind manages to devastate their home planet.
Nuclear fusion as well as manipulation of genes have become daily buisiness in this harsh world ruled by corporate groups.
Journeys to Mars have become possible and science is about to find a way to travel to the stars.

One of Level II's biggest strengths is, that it consists of a ruleset only. No miniatures come with this game!
This way a player may pick any of his miniatures and calculate their point costs referring to the extremely well elaborated and very fine tuned equipment list.
There are rules for about everything that has ever set it's metal or plastic foot on a futuristic war-torn gametable:
Humans, aliens, different kinds of humanoids, tough races, weak races, robots, androids, crafts, cannons, artillery, sabotage, special ammunition, cybernetics - everything you could wish for.
Even the equipment table basically covers everything "out there" - maybe you'll have to substitute sometimes some weapons (like a boltpistol with a common pistol), but you will be able to work with everything that you might find in the hands or at the belt of your miniature.

The rulebook covers the basic rules as well as experts' rules and campaign rules.

Even though Level II is designed for small scale skirmishes with only a couple of individual fighters per side, the rules don't prevent you from playing large scale combats as well. 
In that case however players should have only a few different troop types, to keep combat simple.
For example on the one hand you could get about 50 - 100 light weighted fighters for 1000 points, but if you really spice them up, you may field less than 10 tough guys for the same value, too.

Level II uses an unique command system:
The army of a player is divided into several groups (one at least!) consisting of a number of fighters depending on the faction they are fighting for.
Each group gets one command (e.g. "advance"), represented by a chit placed at that group's position. Depending on that command, each fighter of that group may take up to two different actions (mostly moving + something different, like e.g. taking aim).
In order to change that command, certain conditions have to be met (roll versus a certain value with modifiers according to circumstances like e.g. groupleader killed or minimum distance not met) - if the roll fails the command is either changed later or even not at all.
Specialits may act according to their specialities whenever the player sees fit.

Level II plays very realistically: Most weapons kill an unarmoured human with one hit - just as in real life. This way you will have to be very careful with about everything: 
How are you going to spend your points?
Where and (even mor important:) how are you going to move your fighters?
This way, Level II is a very tactical skirmish game where the skill and the experience of a player garantee a victory instead of lucky dierolls.

Name: Bible Wonders
Description:
From the front of the box: "The game of memory & morals."

Memory:  The object of the game is to collect six gold coins.  You travel around the board on one of six different roads.  Movement occurs after turning over a picture that matches the picture next to the next space on the road.  Each road is three pictures long and ends at an inn where you collect the gold coin.  You may then choose to move to whichever road you want to travel next.

Morals:  The pictures next to the roads show the consequences of 18 of Christ's miracles.  The pictures that you turn over to match with them are the same scenes before the miracle occurred.  The rules also contain a short story of "Malek's Journey" wherein he learns the secret of great wealth.

The game comes with instructions, a game board, 6 "Malek" sandal pieces, 6 flat leather purses on which you lay the coins, 18 match pictures, and 42 cardboard coins (6 coins in 7 colors).

Name: Spies&Spooks: The Cold War Edition
Description:
Set in the 1980's, Spies&Spooks is a spy-themed strategy card game in which each player secretly assumes the role of one of eight spy characters. Each player also receives one of eight coded Assignments, which is decoded in the spy's Passport. The combination of the Secret Assignment with the Secret Identity determines how each player can win the game.
Secret Assignments are to gather specific Secret Cards (ie. Missile Secrets, Political Secrets, Computer Secrets, Trade Secrets etc) and smuggle them out of each game by combining them with various Smuggle Cards (Dead Drop, Diplomatic Pouch, Radio Transmission). Assignments carry varying rewards based upon their difficulty.
Depending on their Secret Identity traits, spies may also steal cards from each other, set bombs as traps, kill each other with Dagger Cards, expose other spies identities and/or assignments, or place them in detention in attempting to be the first spy to complete his or her Secret Mission.
Due to the many various combinations of Identities with Assignments, the game is constantly presenting new and different possibilities for players and has great replay value.
A player wins the game by being the first spy to complete his or her Secret Mission. Multiple hands can be played successively, constituting the Great Game.
Source: Publisher Statement

Name: Feeling & Touching
Description:
From Haba's Website:

Various activities about feeling and touching: the beautiful, easy to grasp wooden pieces stimulate free play and foster fine motor skills. The two tactile games introduce first games with rules. A game collection for 1 - 2 players ages 2+.

Name: Memo-Construction Site
Description:
From Haba Website:
The fabric cards are great to hold and won't wrinkle! A picture and memory game for the smallest with 24 pieces made of cotton/polyester, washable.

Size of card approx. 8,5 x 8,5 cm, height 5 mm.

A game with powerful machines for 1 - 4 players ages 2+.

Name: Babylon: Gateway of the Gods
Description:
Epic building in the magnificent city of Babylon.

Players, as nobles of the city, begin with a small pool of Workers, which they assign to a variety of roles in order to earn silver Talents and prestige. They compete with one another to contribute the most resources toward building Babylon's great works, such as the Hanging Gardens and the Ishtar Gate. To do so they will need to expand their pool of Workers, construct Buildings that make more efficient use of their Resources, arrange Caravan and Shipping expeditions to bring goods back to the city, and deal with the Events that befall the lands.

The game includes:
Game Board
80 Worker markers (12 in each player color)
80 Contributor markers (20 in each player color)
4 Player Tableaus
8 Boats
8 Camels
various Resource chips
40 Event Cards
100 silver Talents

Name: Deadly Double
Description:
A simple dice game with two special dice and depending on the symbols or numbers rolled you add another ante, get part of or the whole jackpot.

Famous for the ad for the game as a hint to a conspiracy theory. The ad shows, among others, the numbers 12 and 7 and talks about peoples in airraid shelters in November 1941. This led to a FBI investigation to see if it was a secret code by the Japanese Intelligence Agency for the attack on Pearl Harbour to warn their agents in the US.

The investigation led to a negative result, but the fame of the game stayed.

Name: Super 3 Game Box
Description: 3 simple games for children come in 1 box: Jet Squadron, Rockets around the Moon and Uranium.  The game play is nothing but roll and move but the graphic presentation is appealing.

Name: Feed the Elephant
Description: Early 1950's game of flicking peanuts into an elephant's mouth.  First player to 12 wins.
